title.narrative: Enhancing Land Border Management Information Systems in Nigeria-Seme Border

description.narrative: The Seme border is considerably one of the most important border regions in the West African frontier between Nigeria and Benin, being one of the busiest land routes used for travelling and commerce as both the Nigerian and Benin economies are dependent on cross-border trade. While the border is replete with border security agencies, there is also the prevalence of criminal activities, ranging from the trafficking of humans, illicit goods and drugs, which extend beyond national boundaries. To support the Federal Government of Nigeria in its efforts to process the identities of individuals upon entering or exiting the country as well as foreigner registration and regularisation; manage migration, curb the growing criminal activities across land borders and promote responsible and orderly migration in the country, IOM launched the MIDAS initiative which can be deployed in states. The system is based on an automated acquisition of standardised and interoperable data set that comprises individuals' biometrical (open standards ICAO and NIST compliant) and biographical information, basic travel document information, as well as additional relevant data as a fully operational Border Management Information System (BMIS) serves a critical role in facilitating and securing cross-border movements while preventing irregularities and crime.
